description.p: Connecting with the thunderclouds above him, a tall tiefling opens a small rift next to him, reaches in and draws out a spear, made of lightning and crackling with energy.

Weaving her hands over the bucket of dirty water, a gnome’s companions saw how the dirt seemed to seperate from it and float into the gnome’s hand while the remaining, now clean water started to boil.

Elementalists draw their power by connecting to the elemental planes through the elements that surround them. Many Elementalists choose to act as a guide to these untamed energies while others believe them to be but tools and shape the elements to their will.

Impartial to anything or anyone, the energies residing within the Elemental Planes still seem to have some sort of alien consciousnes. Through this an elementalist can communicate his ideas and intentions to the elements, manipulating them, shaping them. An Elementalists spells are the elements themselves brought into reality, in whatever shape they occur naturally or otherwise.

Everything, be it man-made or not, is made up of a combination of elements. And these elements, in their core, are linked to the Elemental Planes. Using this connection an elementalist will extract power from these raw and chaotic planes, using it to shape the elements in front of him or creating new structures made from them.
Your background will very likely have a big influence on the approach you choose at 1st level, which will determine what type of elementalist you will be.

In many uncivilized regions for example, Elementalists serve as the spiritual leaders for tribes and clans as they manipulate a dreaded danger to these simple folk, the elements. But they would never dare to fully control them, making them Guides, giving the elements room to run wild while leaving out their people.
Born into a family of wealth might lead you to be a Shaper on the other hand, actively changing and shaping the elements with your will power.

But how did you get to that point? Maybe you served as an apprentice to a Master elementalist, or maybe your natural talent led you to discover it in a situation or peril. How do you feel about other casters, using divine aids or arcane methods to produce similar results? What is your intention with the powers you have? Do you think the elemental planes and the energies within have a purpose, or are they a tool to be used?

You can make an elementalist by following these suggestions. As a Shaper, Charisma should be your highest ability score, followed by Wisdom and Consitution. A Guide on the other hand should have his highest ability score in Wisdom, with Charisma and Constitution as second. Next, choose the folk hero background. Third, choose the ray of frost and elemental attunement cantrips, along with the 1st-level spells ice knife and earth tremor.
As an elementalist, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per elementalist level after 1st
Skills: Choose one from Arcana, History, Religion, Investigation, Survival, Insight, Intimidation, Performance, Persuasion

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a simple weapon or (b) a trident
(a) a component pouch or (b) an arcane focus
(a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack

tr.td: Connection Approach, Spellcasting, Knowledge from the Planes

description.p: At 1st level, you select how your connection to the elements manifests and alters your abilities.

Be it through sheer luck and a drop of talent or study of your surroundings, you’ve found that you can connect to the primal energies that make up the universe. This connection to the building blocks of the world allows you to draw power from the Elemental Planes, either using those energies themselves or letting them fuel your arcane arts.

At first level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the elementalist spell list. You learn additional elementalist cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the elementalist table.

The elementalist table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these elementalist spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
description.h5: SPELLS KNOWN OF 1ST LEVEL OR HIGHER
description.p: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the elementalist spell list. The Spell Known column of the elementalist table shows when you learn more elementalist spells of your choice from this feature. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots on the elementalist table. Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the elementalist spells you know from this feature and replace it with another spell from the elementalist spell list. The new spell must also be of a level for which you have spell slots on the elementalist table.

Your spellcasting ability depends on how you approach the connection to the elements. If you exact a lot of will upon the elements to do your bidding, like you do as a Shaper of Wielder, Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your elementalist spells. But if you want to act as more of a guiding medium for the chaotic, raw energies of the elements, like Guides do, Wisdom is your spellcasting ability. You use your Charisma or Wisdom repsectively whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma or Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for an elementalist spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

center.p: Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma/Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Charisma/Wisdom modifier

description.p: You can use an elemental focus as a spellcasting focus for your elementalist spells

Starting at first level, you can meditate for 1 hour to exchange memories and knowledge with the elemental planes. You can replace one spell you know with another spell of the same level from the elementalist spell table.
Once you’ve used this feature you can’t use it again until you’ve finished a long rest.

sheet.description: You can meditate for 1 hour to exchange memories and knowledge with the elemental planes. You can replace one spell you know with another spell of the same level from the elementalist spell table.

description.p: At second level, you can choose one option from the Environmental Weave list. Whenever you cast a cantrip you can add one of these effects to the effects of the cantrip.

There are always two elements abundant enough in your surroundings for you to use them, a primary and a secondary element (examples listed in the Biomic Elements table below). Weaving them into your cantrips will change and improve them depending on which element you use. The strength of these effects increases if you use the primary element.
You learn additional options at 5th and 10th level and can choose to replace one option whenever you level up.

sheet.description: Whenever you cast a cantrip, you can add an environmental weave effect to the effects of the cantrip.
Whenever you cast a spell or a cantrip, you can add an environmental weave effect to the effects of the cantrip.

description.p: Using the dominant elements in the area you can influence the spell to cover more area.
The range of the spell increases by 15 feet. If its range is touch, its range becomes 15 feet. These values double if air is the primary element in the area.
If the spell has an area of effect, the area increases by 5 feet. This bonus doubles if earth is the primary element in the area.

If the spell has a single target you can target an additional target within 5 feet of the original target. It takes half the damage of the original one. The radius doubles if fire is the primary element in the area.
You can ignore half cover with your spell. You can ignore full cover if water is the primary element in the area.

sheet.description: Using the dominant elements in the area you can influence the spell to cover more area.

description.p: Using the dominant elements in the area you can influence the spell’s effectiveness.
If the spell crits, roll an additional damage die. You gain advantage on the attack roll if air is the primary element in the area.
The spells save DC increases by 1. This bonus doubles if earth is the primary element in the area.
The spell deals additional fire damage equal to half your proficiency bonus. This bonus increases to your full proficiency bonus if fire is the primary element in the area.
The spell gains +1 to hit. This bonus doubles if water is the primary element in the area.

sheet.description: Using the dominant elements in the area you can influence the spell’s effectiveness.

description.p: Using the dominant elements in the area you can tweak the spell’s nature.
Using the air around you to resonate with the weave, you can cast a spell without verbal components. You can also forego somatic components if air is the primary element in the area.

You can use an action to carve a rune into the ground containing the spell. You can use a bonus action to activate the spell as long as you can see the rune. The spell will then originate from the runes location. You can only have one of these runes active at any point. The number of runes you can have is doubled if earth is the primary element in the area.
When you ready a spell you can add your caster level to concentration checks for holding it. You also gain advantage if fire is the primary element in the area.

Hitting a target again with the same spell as last turn will let you apply a stack of cold energy. As a bonus action on your turn you can consume those stacks to decrease the targets movement speed by 5 feet per stack consumed for one round. If that reduces the targets speed to 0, it has to succeed in Consitution saving throw against your Spell Save DC or be stunned for one round. The amount of stacks applied is doubled if water is the primary element in the area.

sheet.description: Using the dominant elements in the area you can tweak the spell’s nature.
Depending on your location, you can add different primary and secondary environmental effects to your spells.
You can use all elements for any elementalist feature and they always use the primary bonus for your environmental or arcane weave.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see Chapter 6 for a list of feats).
Starting at 9th level, you can now also add environmental weave features to spells that require spell slots.

sheet.description: You can now also add environmental weave features to spells that require spell slots.

description.p: Starting at 17th level, you can now use all elements for any elementalist feature and they always use the primary bonus for your environmental or arcane weave.

At 20th level, your ability to weave the elements into your spells has become almost godlike. You can use two different weave methods using different elements at the same time for any spell (or cantrip) you cast.

sheet.description: You can use two different weave methods using different elements at the same time for any spell (or cantrip) you cast.

description.p: Shapers have dedicated themselves to the art of exerting control over the elements. Aware that this will diminish the force of these elements, a Shaper still values reliability over raw power. Using everything the elements can provide, they shape them to their will, finding the right strings to pull at the right time to exert total control over these usually chaotic energies.

Over the centuries, countless mages have studied the elemental planes and a lot of research has been dedicated to them. And while many try to harness the elements through manipulating the arcane weave, some have managed to find a more intuitive approach to tapping into these powers.
When you choose this approach at 1st level, you gain proficiency in Insight. A Shaper finds the weak links in order to impose their own will upon the elements.
Also, you use Charisma as your spellcasting ability.

When you choose this approach at first level, you want to use the elements to their fullest by shaping them to your will. The amount of influence you have over these wild and chaotic energies is represented by a number of control points. The number of control points you have is determined by your Insight modifier.
You can spend these points to fuel various shaping features. You start knowing three such features. You learn more shaping features as you gain levels in this class.
When you spend a control point, it is unavailable until you finish long rest. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest studying the elemental structure of an object of your choice.

When an ally within 30 feet of you is in danger you can use your reaction to help them. When they would get hit by an attack, using 3 control points, you can grant them +2 to AC or +4 to a saving throw.

As a bonus action, you can reach into the Elemental Planes and draw out a weapon of your choice that lacks the two-handed or ammunition property. You are proficient with the weapon and when you attack with that weapon, you can use your Charisma modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls. You can spend a number of control points equal to your proficiency bonus to add additional effects. Unless stated otherwise, you can only add an effect once:
The weapon deals an additional 1d4 of acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage. This damage increases to 1d8 at 11th level and 2d8 at 17th level.
The weapon has +1 on attack rolls. You can apply this effect multiple times.
You can create a weapon with the two-handed property. The heavy property doesn’t effect you if you are a small creature.

The weapon deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage instead of its normal damage. You can also create a weapon with the ammunition property this way, using elemental energy as its projectiles.

As a action on your turn you can spend control points to draw on the elements, covering your body in elemental energy brought into shape. You gain +1 to AC per control point spent and resistance to one of acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage for 1 minute. You can spend a number of control points equal to your proficiency bonus.

At first level, you learn the Control Flames, Gust, Mold Earth and Shape Water cantrips which count as elementalist cantrips for you. You can cast multiple of them simultaneously up to a maximum equal to your proficiency bonus at the same time.

Starting at 6th level, you can use your bonus action and 2 control points to convert raw materials into products of the same material. For example, you can fabricate a wooden bridge from a clump of trees, a rope from a patch of hemp, and clothes from flax or wool. This process takes 6 seconds for a small object, 1 minute for a medium object and 10 minutes for Large objects.

Choose raw materials that you can see within range. You can fabricate a Large or smaller object (contained within a 10-foot cube, or eight connected 5-foot cubes), given a sufficient quantity of raw material. If you are working with metal, glas, or another highly processed material, however, the fabricated object can be no larger than Medium (contained within a single 5-foot cube). The quality of objects made by the spell is commensurate with the quality of the raw materials.

Creatures or magic items can’t be created or transmuted by this spell. You also can’t use it to create items that ordinarily require a high degree of craftsmanship, such as jewelry, weapons, glass, or armor, unless you have proficiency with the type of artisan’s tools used to craft such objects.

Starting at 14th level, you can use 4 control points and your action to call forth an Elemental of an element available in the area (see the Biomic Elements table for that) from your rift to fight alongside you. The elemental is friendly to you and your companions for the duration. Roll initiative for the elemental, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you). If you don’t issue any commands to the elemental, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions. It automatically disappears after 1 hour, when you summon another elemental or when it is dismissed by you.

Starting at 18th level, you can use control points to change the damage type of any spell you cast to acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage. The number of points it costs is equal to the level of the spell slot used to cast the spell divided by 2 rounded down.

A Guide thinks that the chaotic energies in the elemental planes only wait to be given a direction. Believing that the elements are something primal that can’t be controlled, a Guide wants to act as a medium, to give those forces a goal. They use their natural perception for their surroundings to find the right ways to give the elements a little push in the right direction.

Over the centuries, countless mages have studied the elemental planes and a lot of research has been dedicated to them. And while many try to harness the elements through manipulating the arcane weave, some have managed to find a more intuitive approach to tapping into these powers.

When you choose this approach at 1st level, you gain proficiency in Persuasion. Instead of forcing your will on the elements you merely suggest things to them, in order to find success in whatever you want to accomplish.
Also, you use Wisdom as your spellcasting ability.

When you choose this approach at first level, you want to use the elements to their fullest by letting them run free, only gently guiding them. The amount of guidinance you can offer these wild and chaotic energies is represented by a number of synergy points. The number of synergy points you have is determined by your Persuasion modifier.
You can spend these points to fuel various Guide features.
When you spend a synergy point, it is unavailable until you finish long rest. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest meditating in front of your rift.

Starting at 1st level, as an action on your turn, you can open a small rift between the Material Plane and the Elemental Planes next to you. This rift is small in size but occupies 5ft of space. You can move the rift up to 20 feet as a bonus action on your turn. You can cast spells as though you were in the rifts space.

Additionally, utilizing this rift, you’ve learned to unleash the chaotic energies within the elemental planes in a few ways. As an action can spend two synergy points to create one of the following effects:

Make a ranged spell attack against one target within 60 feet of your rift. On a hit the target takes 2d6 damage. Choose one of the d6s. The number it rolled determines the type of damage as shown in the Chaotic Elements table below.

Each creature in a 5-foot radius around your rift must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save it takes 2d6 damage, or half as much damage on a successful one. Choose one of the d6s. The number it rolled determines the type of damage, as shown in the Chaotic Elements table below.

One creature within 30 feet of your rift must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save roll 1d6 to determine the effect it suffers for one round as shown in the Chaotic Elements table below.
Starting at 6th level, your understanding of the chaotic energies welling inside the Elemental Planes allows you to use them to your advantage.

If you roll the same number on both d6s for your Chaotic Missle or Chaotic Burst, you can spend one synergy point to roll an additional d6 and add the result to the total damage dealt. Repeat this process until you don’t roll the same result anymore and use the last die rolled to determine the damage type.
If this occurs at least once, you can add your spellcasting ability modifier to the damage of Chaotic Missle and the radius increases by 5 feet for Chaotic Burst.

Starting at 14th level, listening to the Elemental Planes has become natural for you. Whenever you deal damage either by casting a spell through your rift or using an Elemental Gateway feature, this lets you use one synergy point to find the right frequency, allowing you to change and choose the result of one damage die after rolling or reroll all of them. You must then use the new result. You can use this feature only once per round.

Starting at 18th level, you’ve gained access to the true nature of the elements, swirling through the Elemental Planes. Whenever you deal acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage either by casting a spell through your rift or using an Elemental Gateway feature, you can use three synergy points to replace the damage type with its true form (e.g. fire becomes true fire), bypassing any immunity or resistance. If the target is vulnerable to the damage type, it takes triple damage instead.

While Shapers bend the elements to their will in a completely mental way, Wielders use their trained bodies as a conduit to the elements to have a physical grasp on them. This lets them not exact as much control over them as Shapers but, depending on the Wielder, will retain a lot of the original force behind these energies.

Over the centuries, countless mages have studied the elemental planes and a lot of research has been dedicated to them. And while many try to harness the elements through manipulating the arcane weave, some have managed to find a more intuitive approach to tapping into these powers.
When you choose this approach at 1st level, you gain proficiency in Atheltics. As a Wielder you have a perfectly trained body, capable of withstanding elemental energies being channeled through it.
Also, you use Charisma as your spellcasting ability.

When you choose this approach at first level, you let the elements course through your body, enhancing your physical abilities or using it as a conduit. This obviously takes a toll on your body. The amount of strain your body can take represented by a number of conduit points. The number of conduit points you have is determined by your Athletics modifier.
You can spend these points to fuel various wielding features.

When you spend a conduit point, it is unavailable until you finish long rest. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest meditating, feeling for the remnants of the elemental energies inside your muscles and tissue.

Most wielder features require you to hold some form of elemental energy within your body. To get into this state of an infused body, you can spend an action to draw elemental energy of a specific type through your connection to the elemental planes.
You can hold the energy within you for a number of minutes equal to your profiency bonus and you can charge yourself a number of times equal to your Elementalist level per long rest.
Starting at 1st level, you are capable of statically holding elemental energies inside your body, granting you enhanced physical capabilites depending on the element.

As long as you hold fire energy within your body you are resistant to cold damage. Additionally you can use one conduit point and a bonus action to either gain temporary hitpoints equal to your charisma modifier or cure yourself of one disease or neutralize one poison affecting you.

As long as you hold air energy within your body your speed increases by 10 feet and you can add your proficiency bonus to the damage you deal with melee attacks that deal slashing damage. Additionally you can use one conduit point to use a bonus action to take the Dash or Disengage action.

As long as you hold water energy within your body you are resistant to fire damage. Additionally you can use one conduit point to make an unarmed strike as a bonus action on your turn, even if you don’t have any free hands. It deals bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + your strength modifier + your charisma modifier.

As long as you hold earth energy within your body, you gain a base AC of 13 + your Constitution modifier if you aren’t wearing armor. Additionally you can use one conduit point as a reaction to gain advantage on any saving throw against being moved or knocked prone.
Starting at 6th level, you can expend the element within you in one big burst of energy. You can spend 2 conduit points to create on of the following effects depending on the element:

One creature within 60 feet of you must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC. It takes 4d8 fire damage immediately and 1d8 fire damage at the end of its next turn on a failed save or half the initial damage and no damage at the end of its next turn on a successful one.

Each creature in a 15 feet cone of you must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save it gets pushed 15 feet away from you. If it hits a solid object or another creature in this way, both take 1d8 bludgeoning damage. On a failed save it takes 3d8 slashing damage.

A 100 feet long and 5 feet wide line blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each hostile creature in its path must succeed in a Constitution saving throw or take 2d6 cold damage and its speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. Additionally, you can choose any number of allied creatures in the same line. Each of them gains 2d4 temporary hit points.

Each creature in a 15 feet radius around you must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save it gets pulled 10 feet towards you, if it was closer than that it flies past you, and gets knocked prone. If it hits a solid object or another creature in this way, both take 1d8 bludgeoning damage. The 15 feet circle around you is now considered difficult terrain.

As long as you hold elemental energy within your body you can cast a spell you know without requiring a spellslot by using a number of conduit points equal to the spell slot level you wish to use. However, the type of energy you hold within you decides if you can use this feature for a particular spell and the energy is expended after finishing the cast.

div.p: For most of your spells finding the element tied to it is rather easy. E.g. "Levitate" fits Air, "Fireball" fits Fire, and so on. However the use of this feature is mostly at your DM’s discretion.

description.p: Whenever you use your Directed Release feature you can spend an additional conduit point to immediately gather a new, different element in your body, no action required. In addition, if you have used all four elements in the last minute, you gain +2 AC, double speed, +2 to your spellcasting ability modifier and heal for 5 hit points at the end of your turn for one minute, in addition to the Elemental Enhancement bonus of your current element. After you have benefited from this you can no longer gain these benefits until you’ve finished a long rest.
You can use your action to briefly control elemental forces within 30 feet of you, causing one of the following effects of your choice:

ul.li: Create a harmless, instantaneous sensory effect related to air, earth, fire, or water such as a shower of sparks, a puff of wind, a spray of light mist, or a gentle rumbling of stone.
Instantaneously light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a small campfire.
Chill or warm up to 1 pound of nonliving material for up to 1 hour.
Cause earth, fire, water, or mist that can fit within a 1-foot cube to shape itself into a crude form you designate for 1 minute.

description.p: You attempt to break the structure of a spell while it is being cast. If the creature is casting a spell of 3rd level or lower, its spell fails and has no effect. If it is casting a spell of 4th level or higher, make an Insight check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 14 + the spell’s level. On a success, the creature’s spell fails and has no effect. Every creature in a 5 foot radius takes force damage equal to the result you rolled and the DC.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the interrupted spell has no effect if its level is less than or equal to the level of the spell slot you used.

Using a rift to the elemental plane and another one out again, you teleport yourself from your current location to any other spot within range. You arrive at exactly the spot desired. It can be a place you can see, one you can visualize, or one you can describe by stating distance and direction, such as "200 feet straight downward" or "upward to the northwest at a 45-degree angle, 300 feet".

You can bring along objects as long as their weight doesn’t exceed what you can carry. You can also bring one willing creature of your size or smaller who is carrying gear up to its carrying capacity. The creature must be within 5 feet of you when you cast this spell.
Roll a d20. On a 1, you and any creature traveling with you each take 2d6 fire damage. On a 20, you and any creature traveling with you each gain 15 temporary hit points.
If you would arrive in a place already occupied by an object or a creature, you and any creature traveling with you emerge at the closest unoccupied spot instead.

Sickly, turqoise light spreads within a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within range. The light ignores terrain but is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt. It lasts until the spell ends.

When a creature moves into the spell’s area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take 3d12 poison damage, and is poisoned and emits a dim, turqoise light in a 5-foot radius. This light makes it impossible for the creature to benefit from being invisible. The light and the poisoned condition caused by this spell go away when the spell ends.

This spell creates a magical link between a Large or larger boulder or a Large or larger pool of still water within range and another boulder or pool of water, at any distance, on the same plane of existence. You must have touched the destination boulder or pool of water at least once for 1 hour before, spending 200 GP worth of diamond dust for the attunement ritual. For the duration, any creature can step into the target plant and exit from the destination plant by using 5 feet of movement.

A beam of turbulent, swirling energies bursts out from your hand in a 5-foot-wide, 60-foot-line. Each creature in the line must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 5d10 damage of either acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage and is blinded until your next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn’t blinded by this spell.
You can create a new line of energy as your action on any turn, choosing a different type of damage, until the spell ends.

For the duration, a mote of chaotic, swirling energy shines in your hand. It sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. The light is colorful like sunlight falling through a prism.

setters.set: a diamond worth at least 100 GP

description.p: Eight chaotic rays of energy flash from your hand. Each ray is a different color and has a different element corresponding to it. Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw. For each target, roll a d8 to determine which elemental energy affects it.

tr.td: The target takes 10d6 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The target takes 10d6 acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The target takes 10d6 thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The target takes 10d6 poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The target takes 10d6 cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

On a failed save, the target is restrained. It must then make a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If it successfully saves three times, the spell ends. If it fails its save three times, it permanently turns to stone and is subjected to the petrified condition. The successes and failures don’t need to be consecutive; keep track of both until the target collects three of a kind.

On a failed save, the target is blinded. It must then make a Wisdom saving throw at the start of your next turn. A successful save ends the blindness. If it fails that save, the creature is transported to another plane of existence of the DM’s choosing and is no longer blinded. (Typically, a creature that is on a plane that isn’t its home plane is banished home, while other creatures are usually cast into the Elemental planes.)
The target is struck by two rays. Roll twice more, rerolling any 8.
